vehicles.name: HMS Victory (1st Rate)
vehicles.desc: One hundred and four guns across three decks, crewed by over eight hundred men, and the most powerful warship afloat. She is the flagship, the floating command post, the vessel that anchors the centre of the line and absorbs punishment that would break lesser ships. Her sides are oak three feet thick at the waterline.
vehicles.notes: The 1st rate is a set-piece, not a random encounter. She appears at Trafalgar, at the Nile, at Copenhagen — the decisive fleet actions where empires are won and lost. If the players are aboard, they're in the middle of history. If she's the enemy, they need a plan that doesn't involve standing in front of her guns.

vehicles.name: 5th-Rate Frigate
vehicles.desc: The eyes of the fleet. Fast enough to scout, powerful enough to fight anything short of a ship of the line, and small enough that a brave captain can handle her with daring rather than brute force. Every ambitious young officer in the Royal Navy dreamed of a frigate command.
vehicles.notes: The frigate is your player vessel. She's the right size for a small party to have meaningful roles, fast enough for exciting chases, and strong enough to survive a broadside or two. Build your campaign around a frigate and everything else scales naturally.

vehicles.name: Brig-Sloop
vehicles.desc: Fourteen guns, a hundred men, and orders to patrol the coast. She's the smallest vessel in the navy that counts as a proper warship, commanded by a commander rather than a captain. Every smuggler, privateer, and blockade runner in the Channel knows the brig-sloops by name.
vehicles.notes: The brig-sloop is your patrol vessel. She's too small for fleet actions but perfect for coastal adventures — hunting smugglers, intercepting dispatches, blockade running, and single-ship duels with enemy corvettes. Perfect for a lower-stakes campaign where the players aren't saving the world, just doing their job.

vehicles.name: Revenue Cutter
vehicles.desc: A single mast, a sharp bow, and the ability to sail closer to the wind than anything else afloat. The Revenue Service uses cutters to catch smugglers. The navy uses them to carry dispatches. Smugglers use them to outrun the Revenue Service. Everyone agrees: nothing sails faster in coastal waters.
vehicles.notes: The cutter is your speed boat. She wins every chase in light wind and coastal waters. Use her for dispatch runs, intelligence missions, and smuggling operations where the cargo is small but the consequences of getting caught are enormous.

vehicles.name: Gunboat
vehicles.desc: A flat-bottomed hull with a single heavy cannon mounted in the bow. She's barely seaworthy, she rolls in any kind of swell, and her crew of twenty sleep in shifts because there isn't room for hammocks. But she draws two feet of water and carries a gun that can crack a frigate's hull.
vehicles.notes: Gunboats fight in swarms. One is a nuisance. Ten are a nightmare. Use them in harbour defence scenarios where the players' larger vessel is trapped in shallow water and surrounded by small boats that individually can't hurt them but collectively can pound them to pieces.

vehicles.name: Bomb Vessel
vehicles.desc: Two massive mortars, a reinforced hull to absorb the recoil, and the ability to anchor a mile offshore and lob explosive shells over any fortification ever built. The bomb vessel turned coastal forts from impregnable strongholds into expensive targets.
vehicles.notes: The bomb vessel brings siege warfare to the sea. Use her when the players need to crack a coastal fortification, or when the enemy brings one against the players' harbour. The shells come in at high angle — there's no dodging behind a wall when the shells fall from above.

vehicles.name: Razee
vehicles.desc: A ship of the line that's been cut down — literally. The upper gun deck removed, reducing her to a heavy frigate with the structural strength of a battleship. She's faster than a 74-gun ship and tougher than any true frigate. An ugly compromise that works better than it has any right to.
vehicles.notes: The razee is your ace in the hole. She looks like a frigate from a distance, so enemies assume they can fight her. They're wrong. She hits harder and takes more punishment than any frigate they've met. Use her as a surprise — the 'frigate' the players engage turns out to be a razee, and suddenly they're outgunned.

vehicles.name: Schooner
vehicles.desc: Two masts, fore-and-aft rigged, and faster on a reach than anything her size. The preferred vessel for privateers, smugglers, and anyone who values speed and weatherliness over raw firepower. She trades guns for agility and weathers like a dream.
vehicles.notes: The schooner is the privateer's choice. She's fast, agile, and can run from anything she can't fight. Use her for privateering campaigns, intelligence operations, or any scenario where the players need to be somewhere quickly and quietly.

vehicles.name: Mortar Barge
vehicles.desc: Flat-bottomed, non-seagoing, and carrying a single enormous mortar. She's towed into position, anchored, and fires. She exists for one purpose: river and harbour bombardment. She is, to be blunt, a floating gun platform and nothing more.
vehicles.notes: The mortar barge is a river siege weapon. She can't move under her own power, can't survive open water, and has no business in a ship-to-ship fight. But in a river siege, she's devastating. Use her in any scenario where both sides are fighting over a waterway.

vehicles.name: Ship's Longboat
vehicles.desc: Every warship carries one. Twenty feet of clinker-built oak, six oars, a removable mast, and room for twenty men. She ferries crew to shore, carries water casks, tows the ship in a calm, and leads cutting-out expeditions against enemy vessels in harbour.
vehicles.notes: The longboat is where small-unit action happens. Cutting-out expeditions — rowing into an enemy harbour at night, boarding an anchored vessel, cutting her cables, and sailing her out under fire — are the most dramatic small-scale naval actions of the era. Build an adventure around one.
